title: Monday, 19th December, 2016

11:12 am

Not helped, though,by Astrazeneca.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,325, down 76 (-1.73%), High: 4,426, Low: 4,318, Volume: 599.98k
BE11:13am

Which could've put out news, but hasn't.

11:13 am
PM11:13am

On what?

BE11:13am

Mondher Mahjoubi is off.

BE11:14am

He formerly ran Medimmune's Oncology side.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Ah

BE11:14am

And is now off to join Innate Pharma as executive Chairman.

BE11:14am

This might be quite significant news ....

11:14 am
BE11:14am

... it's certainly weird timing

BE11:15am

... for the head of AZN's Immunicorn department to decide he'd rather be elsewhere.

PM11:15am

Bio:

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Mondher Mahjoubi, MD, joined AstraZeneca in 2013 to lead the oncology therapy area within Global Product and Portfolio Strategy (GPPS). He is part of the GPPS leadership team and is based in Gaithersburg, US.

BE11:15am

That's the one. Here's Dr Andrew Baum, MD, of Citi.

BE11:15am

Dr Mahjoubi has been a close associate of the CEO Pascal Soriot since the latter joined the company in 2012. Not dissimilar to BMY, there has been significant turnover in senior management of AZN and Medimmune oncology over the last 2 years. Recent departures include Ramy Ibrahim (Parker Institute), Antoine Yver (Daiichi), Ed Bradley, Rachel Humphrey (Cytomx) and, Peter Emtage. AZN has replaced these individuals with several key hires from BMY (David Berman), Rob Iannone (MRK). We note the significant influence of Sean Bohen (previously Genentech) on AZN development and communication strategy since he joined the group in 2012. We also note that AZN has a significant deal with Innate on their NKT2A inhibitor, monalizumab, struck in 2015.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

The timing of Dr Mahjoubi’s departure from AZN to Innate Pharma is at the very least surprising, coming ahead of both AZN’s MYSTIC and Innate’s EFFIKIR read outs. The absence of a press release from AZN suggests to us that Dr Mahjoubi’s departure was likely equally surprising to the company. AZN has independently cited to us that Dr Mahjoubi is keen to return to France for personal reasons. We continue to prefer BUY rated AZN, GSK and Roche among the EU majors. We prefer BUY rated BMY and LLY among the US names.

PM11:16am

BE11:17am

When did I last have a rant about the high chances that immuno-oncology is a busted flush, both from an investment perspective and more importantly from a patient one?

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Oh, last week: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2016-12-15/

BE11:17am

Best not retread the ground.

undefined
11:18 am
PM11:18am

How about this BP deal with Apple Dubai?

PM11:18am

Sorry, Abu Dhabi

BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 492.55, up 2.85 (+0.58%), High: 494.45, Low: 489.20, Volume: 8.36m
11:18 am
PM11:18am

Was a bit leftfield -- to me at least

PM11:19am

No price reaction

BE11:19am

Yeah, announce an Apple Dubai farm-in and a Mauritania farm-in on the same day.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

But seemed rather positive to me -- getting back into AD for no cash outlay

BE11:20am

Strategically, it's interesting. One could see it as finally moving on from Macondo and getting the reserve base up again.

PM11:20am

Of course you could read the fact that it paid in stock as evidence of "capital constraint"

11:20 am
PM11:20am

As UBS does

PM11:20am

Here's three pars

PM11:21am

BP on Saturday agreed to acquire a 10% stake in the 40 year ADCO onshore concession in Abu Dhabi (the majority of its onshore production). BP also becomes the leader for the licence's Bab assets. ADCO will add ~165kbd of production to BP (

7% of non-Rosneft) and 2-3bn boe of resources. BP held a 9.5% stake until the concession expired in 2014. BP re-joins fellow IOC Total in re-signing for a 10% stake (Total has become the technical leader of the Bu Hasa assets). The elapsed time since the previous concession ended and the Total deal suggest terms have continued to be re-negotiated.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Sorry for formatting

PM11:21am

By way of consideration, BP will issue 393m ordinary shares to Abu Dhabi. This represents a 2.1% capital increase and a cost of $2.36bn at the Friday closing ($2.19bn at the reference share price). Total did not specifically disclose the price paid for its stake but showed a $2.220bn license bonus paid to the Abu Dhabi government in its 2015 annual report suggesting the principal is similar if not the same. The need to use shares, and not cash as Total did, highlights the tight capital constraint BP operates under with gearing at 25.9% at 3Q16 plus an equivalent ~9% of Macondo obligations.

PM11:21am

We confess this type of transaction does not immediately excite us. But we recognise the need to have downside protection, scale and long-term visibility in a portfolio. The terms of the new ADCO concession have not been made public but we think are likely a fixed or semi-fixed margin with some upside for the asset leader role. BP indicates this transaction is accretive to earnings and cashflow. We would infer that the RoR is less than the target 15% IRR for a new greenfield but above the 7% implied dividend yield at the 447p reference. The longer-term evolution of BP's Upstream portfolio suggests some de-risking and re-balancing underway with a greater proportion of longer life assets and lower reinvestment risk plus near term BP has become quite active in supplementing its portfolio – with purchases of stakes in Zohr (Egypt) and deepening in Tangguh (Indonesia) most recently (and Aker-BP earlier in 2016).

11:22 am
PM11:22am

Ive nothing much to add on that

BE11:22am

Yeah, okay. Bit more from BMO .....

BE11:22am

... which picks up also on the Senegal deal.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

In and ahead of the holiday season, BP has announced a $2.4 billion all share farm-in to ADCO for 10% W.I. and a ~$1 billion farm-in to Kosmos Energy's Senegal/Mauritania discovered gas (greater than 25Tcf) and oil exploration assets. The increased resource capture activity by BP, including the 10-15% farm-in to Eni's Zohr, and FID at Mad Dog II is BP's response, we believe, to 2020+ growth concerns.

BE11:23am

Key Points
• ADCO: 10% for $2.4 billion in shares. The deal is expected to be cash flow and earnings accretive, and provide BP with attractive returns considering the long duration, low risk, and low cost nature of the production resource.

• The concession is 40 years and is underpinned by a 20-30 billion boe resource.
ADCO's gross 2016 production is expected to be ~1.66 Mboepd. The deal implies a
~$1/boe finding cost, and we understand that the terms are different to what had been originally offered in 2014.

• Senegal/Mauritania: BP has announced the acquisition of stakes in assets in Mauritania and Senegal from Kosmos Energy (KOS-US, $5.73, Outperform, TP: $8/sh) for ~$1 billion: 1) $162m cash up front, 2) $221m E&A carry on Tortue by 2017, and 3) $553m max development carry upon FID. The deal also includes a sliding scale contingent bonus of up to $2/bbl for 1 bn bbl as a production royalty.

• Capex $15-17 billion in 2017 expected to be maintained: ADCO, Zohr, and Senegal/ Mauritania will put some pressure on BP's capex budget for 2017+; however, we believe BP will keep within its $15-17 billion capex range guidance. BP is continuing
to see cost deflation and efficiency gains.

BE11:23am

• Our view remains positive. We believe BP's shopping spree is the company's response to what the investor community has long been concerned about: long-term growth and resource sustenance. We expected BP to acquire resources in order to replenish its relatively lean portfolio post Macondo. BP's timing might have also been triggered by what it sees as a likely recovery in the oil price and asset values over 2017.

Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 346.70, up 22.7 (+7.01%), High: 358.90, Low: 334.40, Volume: 1.24m
11:28 am
BE11:28am

The power station operator whose business model seems to be in a permanent state of flux.

BE11:29am

Two bits of news, most notably from the EU

BE11:29am

Which has approved biomass subsidies

11:30 am
BE11:30am

BRUSSELS, Dec 19 (Reuters) - The European Commission on Monday approved Britain's plans to support the conversion of a unit of the Drax power plant from coal to biomass, sending shares in the London-listed company to a five-month high.

The Commission opened an investigation into the proposed state aid in January to check that it would not lead to overcompensation and distort competition in the biomass market.

It said on Monday the project would further the European Union's environmental and energy targets.

The UK government plans to support the conversion by guaranteeing a minimum price for electricity generated by the plant.

"On the basis of this analysis, the Commission has now concluded that the planned premium will not result in overcompensation," the Commission said in a statement.

BE11:30am

And secondly, SocGen

BE11:31am

... which timed its Drax upgrade to buy quite exceptionally well.

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Certainly did

BE11:31am

Historically, SocGen's been a seller

BE11:32am

All the way from £8 to £2.50

11:32 am
BE11:32am

But had been on hold for the past year awaiting the CfD clearance news ....

BE11:04am

Yep, it seems to be working,

BE11:34am

We are upgrading Drax from Hold to Buy and increasing our target price from 270p to 415p (+32% TSR). The catalyst to our more positive view is the 6 December indication from management that State aid approval for the £100/MWh 3rd unit biomass CfD should be received very soon and will come without amendment to terms. In isolation, the CfD approval should add around £100m p.a. of EBITDA and greater than £1 per share of value and also bring balance sheet and W/C benefits and revenue and regulatory stability. At 415p Drax would be on a FY18e 6.5x EV/EBITDA and 18% FCF yield.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

18%!

PM11:34am

Extraordinary

BE11:35am

Despite short asset life, current valuation compelling post CfD approval. At our
target share price of 415p we estimate Drax would be trading on a FY18 PE of 11.8x, an
EV/EBITDA of 6.5x and a DY of 4.2% (50% payout). Its FCF yield post an assumed £40m
of maintenance capex (from FY18 onwards) is an estimated 17.5%.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Limited upside potential from 4th unit conversion – carbon pricing remains a risk (as
per other low carbon generators). We estimate a fourth unit conversion at a £80/MWh CfD
strike price could add between 10-15p of value – but in our view it remains a low
possibility. The removal of the UK’s £18/t carbon price support from 2021 would have a
more material 90p negative impact – although this is a risk not discounted in the share
prices of other carbon-tax-sensitive power generators.

PM11:37am

PM11:37am

11:37 am

11:47 am
Carnival PLC (CCL:LSE): Last: 3,993, down 75 (-1.84%), High: 4,005, Low: 3,870, Volume: 304.10k
BE11:48am

The endlessly fascinating debate about cruise ship capacity additions, local port proximity and wave season discounting.

BE11:49am

Berenberg's worried.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Our view in a nutshell: We remain positive about the outlook for yields in the cruise industry going into 2017. However, recent trends in the cost of fuel, a further strengthening of the dollar and an increase in interest rates create headwinds that we think will be tough for Carnival to offset. We reduce our price target to $50 (plc: £40) and lower our recommendation from Buy to Hold.

BE11:49am

Solid yield growth in 2017 undermined by currency: We expect yield growth for Carnival to remain strong on a constant currency basis, improving by c3% on 2016. However, a further strengthening of the dollar since the company has announced its third quarter results means that we think that the drag on yields has risen, so reported yields will be under 1%.

BE11:50am

Costs well controlled but increased dry dock days: We continue to expect carnival to keep costs under control and manage to deliver the $70m to $80m of savings necessary to offset inflation. However, the company has flagged that it will face around 90 more dry dock days, which we estimate will cost up to $100m. That means we expect costs excluding fuel per available lower berth day (ALBD) to rise next year by around 1.5%.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Fuel prices continue to rise: At the third quarter results, Carnival indicated that higher fuel costs would be a $0.24 drag on earnings in 2017, or c$175m. With fuel costs guided to be $926m in 2016, this implied c$1.1bn at the time. We believe that this cost has risen by a further $150m, with bunker fuel up by around c20% since the third quarter results.

BE11:50am

Risk of higher interest costs: The recent increase in US rates will also likely lead to a small rise in the cost of debt, which we estimate will be around 10bp on the average cost of debt. This reflects the fact that much of Carnival’s debt is either fixed rate or is denominated in euros, where we do not expect interest rises.

BE11:51am

Leaves our EPS expectations for next year broadly flat: Once we take into account all of these moving parts, we are now expecting EPS in 2017F to come in at $3.37 compared to our forecast of $3.38 for this year. This is a 9% drop compared to where we were previously, and is 8% below consensus. With our valuation based on a 15x P/E in line with historical averages, this gives us a new price target of $50 (plc: £40) per share, implying 4% downside.

11:52 am
BE11:52am
